elements.content: An efficient synthetic route to an A1/A2-difunctionalized pillar[5]arene containing resolvable planar chirality has been developed and the arene employed as a strut in the synthesis of P5A-MOF-1, which has been demonstrated by X-ray powder diffraction analysissupported by modelingto be isoreticular with MOF-5. This metal–organic framework has an active domain that expresses good and selective uptake of neutral and positively charged electron-poor aromatic guests, which effect color changes of the cubic crystals from faint yellow to deep orange, arising from charge transfer between the guests and active domain of P5A-MOF-1.
elements.clean_text: An efficient synthetic route to an A1/A2-difunctionalized pillar[5]arene containing resolvable planar chirality has been developed and the arene employed as a strut in the synthesis of P5A-MOF-1, which has been demonstrated by X-ray powder diffraction analysissupported by modelingto be isoreticular with MOF-5. This metal-organic framework has an active domain that expresses good and selective uptake of neutral and positively charged electron-poor aromatic guests, which effect color changes of the cubic crystals from faint yellow to deep orange, arising from charge transfer between the guests and active domain of P5A-MOF-1.

elements.content: Macrocycles such as cyclodextrins, crown ethers, calixarenes, cucurbiturils, and cyclophanes have become an integral part of host–guest chemistry. A relatively new class of macrocycles to enter the field, the pillararenes, are analogues of calixarenes composed of five, six, or seven hydroquinone rings linked through their para-positions by methylene bridges. Since pillar[5]arene was first introduced as a novel macrocycle by Ogoshi and co-workers in 2008, the chemistry of the pillararenes has been developed steadily, and they have been shown to have applications in liquid crystals, artificial transmembrane channels, nanoparticle formation, and sensing. Here we report the synthesis of an A1/A2-difunctionalized pillar[5]arene that undergoes cross-coupling reactions to create a rigid strut which is then incorporated into a metal–organic framework (MOF) having an active domain containing docking sites for electron-poor guests.
elements.clean_text: Macrocycles such as cyclodextrins, crown ethers, calixarenes, cucurbiturils, and cyclophanes have become an integral part of host-guest chemistry. A relatively new class of macrocycles to enter the field, the pillararenes, are analogues of calixarenes composed of five, six, or seven hydroquinone rings linked through their para-positions by methylene bridges. Since pillar[5]arene was first introduced as a novel macrocycle by Ogoshi and co-workers in 2008, the chemistry of the pillararenes has been developed steadily, and they have been shown to have applications in liquid crystals, artificial transmembrane channels, nanoparticle formation, and sensing. Here we report the synthesis of an A1/A2-difunctionalized pillar[5]arene that undergoes cross-coupling reactions to create a rigid strut which is then incorporated into a metal-organic framework (MOF) having an active domain containing docking sites for electron-poor guests.

elements.content: MOFs with organic struts incorporating macrocycles have been used recently to prepare extended frameworks with active domains, which, as a result of highly favorable and specific noncovalent interactions, play host to a well-ordered distribution of guest molecules. In 2009, we described the use of a π-electron-rich BPP34C10-functionalized organic strut in the synthesis of MOF-1001 which was shown to soak up the π-electron-poor guest, methyl viologen. MOFs containing active domains show promise in the fields of chromatographic separation and sensing, thereby making designer organic struts containing novel macrocycles attractive synthetic targets.
elements.clean_text: MOFs with organic struts incorporating macrocycles have been used recently to prepare extended frameworks with active domains, which, as a result of highly favorable and specific noncovalent interactions, play host to a well-ordered distribution of guest molecules. In 2009, we described the use of a π-electron-rich BPP34C10-functionalized organic strut in the synthesis of MOF-1001 which was shown to soak up the π-electron-poor guest, methyl viologen. MOFs containing active domains show promise in the fields of chromatographic separation and sensing, thereby making designer organic struts containing novel macrocycles attractive synthetic targets.

elements.content: We have developed a synthetic protocol (Scheme ) to obtain an A1/A2-difunctionalized pillar[5]arene organic strut, starting from 1, which is made through the co-cyclization of 1,4-dimethoxybenzene and 1,4-bis(3-bromopropoxy)benzene, similar to our previously reported reaction for preparing monofunctionalized pillar[5]arene. Compound 1 undergoes elimination to give the diallyl ether 2, which was deprotected using standard conditions to give the A1/A2-dihydroxy-pillar[5]arene 3. Single crystals of 3, suitable for X-ray crystallography, were grown; the solid-state structure (Scheme ) of 3 shows that the hydroquinone unit is oriented in a direction opposite to that adopted by the 1,4-dimethoxybenzene units to support two intramolecular hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: We have developed a synthetic protocol (Scheme ) to obtain an A1/A2-difunctionalized pillar[5]arene organic strut, starting from 1, which is made through the co-cyclization of 1,4-dimethoxybenzene and 1,4-bis(3-bromopropoxy)benzene, similar to our previously reported reaction for preparing monofunctionalized pillar[5]arene. Compound 1 undergoes elimination to give the diallyl ether 2, which was deprotected using standard conditions to give the A1/A2-dihydroxy-pillar[5]arene 3. Single crystals of 3, suitable for X-ray crystallography, were grown; the solid-state structure (Scheme ) of 3 shows that the hydroquinone unit is oriented in a direction opposite to that adopted by the 1,4-dimethoxybenzene units to support two intramolecular hydrogen bonds.

elements.content:
Synthesis of A1/A2-Difunctionalized Pillar[5]­arene Organic Strut<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

In the X-ray crystal structure of 3, C is gray, O is red, H is white; alkyl H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of A1/A2-Difunctionalized Pillar[5]arene Organic Strut      a In the X-ray crystal structure of 3, C is gray, O is red, H is white; alkyl H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
In the X-ray crystal structure of 3, C is gray, O is red, H is white; alkyl H atoms are omitted for clarity.

Compound 3, when treated with triflic anhydride, affords the ditriflate 4. Ogoshi and co-workers showed that a pertriflated pillar[5]arene can undergo 10 Pd-catalyzed cross-couplings to give a highly conjugated pillar[5]arene. In similar fashion, 4 can be converted into a rigid strut 5 by means of a Pd-catalyzed Suzuki reaction with 4-(methoxycarbonyl)phenylboronic acid, followed by saponification of the intermediate diester. The solid-state structure of 5 (Figure ) was elucidated by single-crystal X-ray analysis using crystals grown from diffusion of MeOH into a solution of 5 in DMF. The analysis indicates the presence of enantiomers in the unit cell. In keeping with its molecular C 2 symmetry, the 1H NMR spectrum (see ) of 5 displays two pairs of doublets for the two homotopic pairs of constitutionally hetereotopic methylene groupswhere in each case the protons are diastereotopic, given the fact that 5 is conformationally rigidand a singlet for the remaining constitutionally hetereotopic methylene group lying on the C 2 axis, which renders its methylene protons homotopic. The conformational rigidity of the pillar[5]arene-based strut 5 means that it exists as (potentially resolvable) enantiomers, R p and S p (Figure ) due to the molecule’s planar chirality. Compound 5 demonstrates that only two bulky monosubstituted phenyl rings are required at the A1/A2 positions on a pillar[5]arene to impart resolvable planar chirality upon its constitution.
elements.clean_text:
a In the X-ray crystal structure of 3, C is gray, O is red, H is white; alkyl H atoms are omitted for clarity.  

Compound 3, when treated with triflic anhydride, affords the ditriflate 4. Ogoshi and co-workers showed that a pertriflated pillar[5]arene can undergo 10 Pd-catalyzed cross-couplings to give a highly conjugated pillar[5]arene. In similar fashion, 4 can be converted into a rigid strut 5 by means of a Pd-catalyzed Suzuki reaction with 4-(methoxycarbonyl)phenylboronic acid, followed by saponification of the intermediate diester. The solid-state structure of 5 (Figure ) was elucidated by single-crystal X-ray analysis using crystals grown from diffusion of MeOH into a solution of 5 in DMF. The analysis indicates the presence of enantiomers in the unit cell. In keeping with its molecular C 2 symmetry, the 1H NMR spectrum (see ) of 5 displays two pairs of doublets for the two homotopic pairs of constitutionally hetereotopic methylene groupswhere in each case the protons are diastereotopic, given the fact that 5 is conformationally rigidand a singlet for the remaining constitutionally hetereotopic methylene group lying on the C 2 axis, which renders its methylene protons homotopic. The conformational rigidity of the pillar[5]arene-based strut 5 means that it exists as (potentially resolvable) enantiomers, R p and S p (Figure ) due to the molecule's planar chirality. Compound 5 demonstrates that only two bulky monosubstituted phenyl rings are required at the A1/A2 positions on a pillar[5]arene to impart resolvable planar chirality upon its constitution.

elements.content: Solid-state structure of 5 (C is gray, O is red) which displays planar chirality and does not racemize between the R p-5 (left) and S p-5 (right) enantiomers. A DMF molecule and hydrogens have been removed from the structure to aid visual clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Solid-state structure of 5 (C is gray, O is red) which displays planar chirality and does not racemize between the R p-5 (left) and S p-5 (right) enantiomers. A DMF molecule and hydrogens have been removed from the structure to aid visual clarity.

elements.content: The pillar[5]arene-based strut 5 has been used to synthesize a MOF (Figure a) with Zn4O secondary building units (SBUs) which is isoreticular to MOF-5. P5A-MOF-1 was prepared in a conventional manner by heating a mixture of 5 and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in DMF at 100 °C over 24 h. The crystals (Figure a) of P5A-MOF-1 are cubic and transparent. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed their crystallinity (Figure b), while thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to determine their thermal stability: a one-step TGA profile shows that P5A-MOF-1 is stable to 450 °C. Crystals of P5A-MOF-1 were activated using supercritical CO2, and a NLDFT surface area of 300 m2 g–1 was obtained from a CO2 isotherm (see ).
elements.clean_text: The pillar[5]arene-based strut 5 has been used to synthesize a MOF (Figure a) with Zn4O secondary building units (SBUs) which is isoreticular to MOF-5. P5A-MOF-1 was prepared in a conventional manner by heating a mixture of 5 and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in DMF at 100 °C over 24 h. The crystals (Figure a) of P5A-MOF-1 are cubic and transparent. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed their crystallinity (Figure b), while thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to determine their thermal stability: a one-step TGA profile shows that P5A-MOF-1 is stable to 450 °C. Crystals of P5A-MOF-1 were activated using supercritical CO2, and a NLDFT surface area of 300 m2g-1 was obtained from a CO2 isotherm (see ).

elements.content: (a) Model of P5A-MOF-1 (pillar[5]arene macrocycles are red, terphenylene moieties are black, zinc SBUs are yellow). (b) Experimental PXRD pattern for P5A-MOF-1 (black), calculated PXRD patterns for P5A-MOF-1 in a P1 space group (red) and a Pm3m space group (green), and PXRD pattern for IRMOF-16 (blue). See SI for full PXRD of P5A-MOF-1.

(b) Experimental PXRD pattern for P5A-MOF-1 (black), calculated PXRD patterns for P5A-MOF-1 in a P1 space group (red) and a Pm3m space group (green), and PXRD pattern for IRMOF-16 (blue). See SI for full PXRD of P5A-MOF-1.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data obtained for P5A-MOF-1 were not well enough resolved to discern the solid-state structure of the extended framework as a result of disorder within the MOF itself. We believe this disorder arises principally from the rotational freedom of pillar[5]arenes around every terphenylene linker in the extended structure and a random distribution of “enantiomeric” pillar[5]arenes associated with their planar chirality.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray data obtained for P5A-MOF-1 were not well enough resolved to discern the solid-state structure of the extended framework as a result of disorder within the MOF itself. We believe this disorder arises principally from the rotational freedom of pillar[5]arenes around every terphenylene linker in the extended structure and a random distribution of "enantiomeric" pillar[5]arenes associated with their planar chirality.

elements.content: The extended structure of P5A-MOF-1 was modeled (see ) using non-interpenetrated IRMOF-16 as the backbone and incorporating pillar[5]arenes with randomly distributed chiralities and orientations with respect to the terphenylene linkers. The geometry of the predicted structure was optimized to give a cubic unit cell with dimensions of a = b = c = 42.980 Å and a space group of P1. The simulated PXRD pattern of the modeled structure matches closely with the experimental one for P5A-MOF-1 (Figure b). An alternative approach to modeling the extended structure with a Pm3m space group was also pursued to determine if a model with higher symmetry might also fit the experimental MOF data. In this alternative model, each organic strut, ordered throughout the 3D framework, contains four pillar[5]arene rings in the shape of both “enantiomers” in two different orientations, each with a 0.25 occupancy disorder. Although the cubic cell dimensions of the model are identical with those of the first model, the simulated PXRD pattern presents extra peaks (Figure b), including a sharp 001 reflection. Thus, it seems that the lower symmetry model provides a better match with the experimental data.
elements.clean_text: The extended structure of P5A-MOF-1 was modeled (see ) using non-interpenetrated IRMOF-16 as the backbone and incorporating pillar[5]arenes with randomly distributed chiralities and orientations with respect to the terphenylene linkers. The geometry of the predicted structure was optimized to give a cubic unit cell with dimensions of a = b = c = 42.980 Å and a space group of P1. The simulated PXRD pattern of the modeled structure matches closely with the experimental one for P5A-MOF-1 (Figure b). An alternative approach to modeling the extended structure with a Pm3m space group was also pursued to determine if a model with higher symmetry might also fit the experimental MOF data. In this alternative model, each organic strut, ordered throughout the 3D framework, contains four pillar[5]arene rings in the shape of both "enantiomers" in two different orientations, each with a 0.25 occupancy disorder. Although the cubic cell dimensions of the model are identical with those of the first model, the simulated PXRD pattern presents extra peaks (Figure b), including a sharp 001 reflection. Thus, it seems that the lower symmetry model provides a better match with the experimental data.

elements.content: We investigated the ability of P5A-MOF-1 to take up guests (Figure ). At the outset, however, we evaluated the ability of the strut 5 to form complexes with three guests: the PF6 – salts of N-hexylpyridinium cation (G1 + ) and N,N′-dihexyl-4,4-bipyridinium dication (G2 2+), as well as the neutral 1,4-dinitrobenzene (G3). 1H NMR titrations in CD3COCD3 revealed association constants (K a) between 5 and G1·PF6, G2·2PF6, and G3 of 43.2 ± 2.9, 170 ± 50, and 66.2 ± 1.9 M–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text: We investigated the ability of P5A-MOF-1 to take up guests (Figure ). At the outset, however, we evaluated the ability of the strut 5 to form complexes with three guests: the PF6 - salts of N-hexylpyridinium cation (G1  + ) and N,N'-dihexyl-4,4-bipyridinium dication (G2 2+), as well as the neutral 1,4-dinitrobenzene (G3). 1H NMR titrations in CD3COCD3 revealed association constants (K a) between 5 and G1⋅PF6, G2⋅2PF6, and G3 of 43.2 ± 2.9, 170 ± 50, and 66.2 ± 1.9 M-1, respectively.

elements.content: (Top) Optical microscopy images of P5A-MOF-1 (a) with no guest (scale bar, 200 μm), (b) after uptake of G2·2PF6 (scale bar, 100 μm, and (c) after uptake of G3 (scale bar, 100 μm). (Bottom) Electron-poor compounds used in guest uptake studies with P5A-MOF-1: N-hexylpyridinium cation (G1 +), N,N′-dihexyl-4,4-bipyridinium dication (G2 2+), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (G3).
elements.clean_text: 3  (Top) Optical microscopy images of P5A-MOF-1 (a) with no guest (scale bar, 200 μm), (b) after uptake of G2⋅2PF6 (scale bar, 100 μm, and (c) after uptake of G3 (scale bar, 100 μm). (Bottom) Electron-poor compounds used in guest uptake studies with P5A-MOF-1: N-hexylpyridinium cation (G1 +), N,N'-dihexyl-4,4-bipyridinium dication (G2 2+), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (G3).

elements.content: Samples of P5A-MOF-1 were suspended in Me2CO prior to guest uptake experiments to remove excess of DMF from within the framework. The samples were then introduced into saturated solutions of G1·PF6, G2·2PF6, and G3 in Me2CO. With G2·2PF6 and G3, the crystals underwent an immediate color change (Figure b,c) from faint yellow to deep orange upon addition of the guests, most likely because of charge-transfer interactions between the guests and P5A-MOF-1. The MOF samples were allowed to take up guests for 12 h before they were washed with Me2CO and dissolved in DMSO-d 6/TFA-d and their 1H NMR spectra recorded. Integration of appropriate probe protons led to quantification of the uptake of guests by the MOF (Table ). IRMOF-16-OPX, prepared from an oligo-p-xylene (OPX) derivative (S3 in ) of p-terphenyl-4,4″-dicarboxylic acid, was used as a control. Although both P5A-MOF-1 and IRMOF-16-OPX are isoreticular with IRMOF-16, the latter does not have an active domain. The guest uptake experiments were performed under identical conditions for both MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Samples of P5A-MOF-1 were suspended in Me2CO prior to guest uptake experiments to remove excess of DMF from within the framework. The samples were then introduced into saturated solutions of G1⋅PF6, G2⋅2PF6, and G3 in Me2CO. With G2⋅2PF6 and G3, the crystals underwent an immediate color change (Figure b,c) from faint yellow to deep orange upon addition of the guests, most likely because of charge-transfer interactions between the guests and P5A-MOF-1. The MOF samples were allowed to take up guests for 12 h before they were washed with Me2CO and dissolved in DMSO-d 6/TFA-d and their 1H NMR spectra recorded. Integration of appropriate probe protons led to quantification of the uptake of guests by the MOF (Table ). IRMOF-16-OPX, prepared from an oligo-p-xylene (OPX) derivative (S3 in ) of p-terphenyl-4,4"-dicarboxylic acid, was used as a control. Although both P5A-MOF-1 and IRMOF-16-OPX are isoreticular with IRMOF-16, the latter does not have an active domain. The guest uptake experiments were performed under identical conditions for both MOFs.

elements.content:
Mole Ratio of Guest to Organic Strut in <bold>P5A-MOF-1</bold> and <bold>IRMOF-16-OPX</bold>, Obtained from <sup>1</sup>H NMR Spectra after Guest Uptake and Digestion of MOF<xref rid="t1fn1"></xref> P5A-MOF-1 IRMOF-16-OPX Single-Guest Uptake Experiments G1 + 0.755 0.121 G2 2+ 0.366 0.125 G3 0.293 0.084 Two-Guest Uptake Experiments G1 + + G2 2+ 0.091 G1 + /0.176 G2 2+ 0.089 G1 + /0.069 G2 2+ G1 + + G3 0.090 G1 + /0.127 G3 0.027 G1 + /0.032 G3 G2 2+ + G3 0.310 G2 2+ /0.100 G3 0.068 G2 2+ /0.014 G3

Uptake with a single guest was performed with a saturated solution of the guest in Me2CO. Uptake with two guests was performed in a Me2CO solution with each guest at 40.0 mM. K a values of guest with 5 determined by 1H NMR titration in CD3COCD3: G1 + , 43.2 ± 2.9 M–1; G2 2+ , 170 ± 50 M–1; G3, 66.2 ± 1.9 M–1.

P5A-MOF-1 takes up G1·PF6, G2·2PF6, and G3 from their saturated solutions in Me2CO in moderate to high amounts. Table lists the mole ratios of the guest to the organic strut found in the MOF. The fact that, under identical conditions, P5A-MOF-1 takes up a significantly larger amount of each guest than does IRMOF-16-OPX suggests the active domain of P5A-MOF-1 is able to interact with guest molecules through favorable noncovalent bonding interactions. Uptake of adamantane, which has been shown to be too large to reside inside the cavity of pillar[5]arene, but small enough to pass through the pores of either MOF, was similar for both P5A-MOF-1 and IRMOF-16-OPX (see ).
elements.clean_text: P5A-MOF-1 takes up G1⋅PF6, G2⋅2PF6, and G3 from their saturated solutions in Me2CO in moderate to high amounts. Table  lists the mole ratios of the guest to the organic strut found in the MOF. The fact that, under identical conditions, P5A-MOF-1 takes up a significantly larger amount of each guest than does IRMOF-16-OPX suggests the active domain of P5A-MOF-1 is able to interact with guest molecules through favorable noncovalent bonding interactions. Uptake of adamantane, which has been shown to be too large to reside inside the cavity of pillar[5]arene, but small enough to pass through the pores of either MOF, was similar for both P5A-MOF-1 and IRMOF-16-OPX (see ).

elements.content: In a final experiment, P5A-MOF-1 was suspended in Me2CO with equimolar concentrations (40.0 mM) of two different guests to determine if there is preferential uptake of one guest over the other. While we envisioned that the observed guest-to-MOF ratios would depend to some extent on the K a values of the guests with 5 in solution, other factors, including the sizes and diffusion rates of the guests, might also be significant. P5A-MOF-1 showed almost twice the uptake of G2·2PF6 compared to G1·PF6 (Table ), reflecting the larger K a value for the former than the latter in binding 5. Under identical conditions, the uptake by IRMOF-16-OPX of these two guests is very similar, as expected. Comparable results, which reflect ratios of K a values, can be observed when P5A-MOF-1 is exposed to equimolar combinations of the other guests (Table ).
elements.clean_text: In a final experiment, P5A-MOF-1 was suspended in Me2CO with equimolar concentrations (40.0 mM) of two different guests to determine if there is preferential uptake of one guest over the other. While we envisioned that the observed guest-to-MOF ratios would depend to some extent on the K a values of the guests with 5 in solution, other factors, including the sizes and diffusion rates of the guests, might also be significant. P5A-MOF-1 showed almost twice the uptake of G2⋅2PF6 compared to G1⋅PF6 (Table ), reflecting the larger K a value for the former than the latter in binding 5. Under identical conditions, the uptake by IRMOF-16-OPX of these two guests is very similar, as expected. Comparable results, which reflect ratios of K a values, can be observed when P5A-MOF-1 is exposed to equimolar combinations of the other guests (Table ).

elements.content: The rigid stereochemistry associated with the planar chirality of the strut 5 means that it should be possible, after resolving 5, to prepare “enantiomeric” P5A-MOF-1 samples without fear of 5 racemizing during the synthesis (at 100 °C) of the MOF. The prospect of being able to prepare chiral, enantiomerically pure, pillar[5]arene-containing MOFs to separate racemic mixtures of appropriate analytes is being pursued in our laboratories.
elements.clean_text: The rigid stereochemistry associated with the planar chirality of the strut 5 means that it should be possible, after resolving 5, to prepare "enantiomeric" P5A-MOF-1 samples without fear of 5 racemizing during the synthesis (at 100 °C) of the MOF. The prospect of being able to prepare chiral, enantiomerically pure, pillar[5]arene-containing MOFs to separate racemic mixtures of appropriate analytes is being pursued in our laboratories.

elements.content:
Two-dimensional NOESY was employed in the assignment of the 1-D 1H NMR spectrum (see ).

Even at elevated temperatures (100 °C) exchange between the diastereotopic methylene protons is not observed, indicating that the two benzoic acid substituents of 5 render the strut too large to be able to pass through the middle of the annulus which constitutes pillar[5]arene, implying that the inversion between the R p and S p enantiomers (Figure ) does not occur on the NMR time scale, or indeed it would appear, on the laboratory time scale.
elements.clean_text:
Two-dimensional NOESY was employed in the assignment of the 1-D 1H NMR spectrum (see ).

Even at elevated temperatures (100 °C) exchange between the diastereotopic methylene protons is not observed, indicating that the two benzoic acid substituents of 5 render the strut too large to be able to pass through the middle of the annulus which constitutes pillar[5]arene, implying that the inversion between the R p and S p enantiomers (Figure ) does not occur on the NMR time scale, or indeed it would appear, on the laboratory time scale.

elements.content: At room temperature, the 1H NMR spectra (see ) for 1–4 all display three singlets corresponding to the constiutionally heterotopic methylene groups, indicating that the enantiomeric pairs of these pillar[5]arene derivatives are inverting rapidly on the 1H NMR time scale.
elements.clean_text: At room temperature, the 1H NMR spectra (see ) for 1-4 all display three singlets corresponding to the constiutionally heterotopic methylene groups, indicating that the enantiomeric pairs of these pillar[5]arene derivatives are inverting rapidly on the 1H NMR time scale.

elements.content: Further proof that the R p and S p enantiomers of 5 are resolvable comes from its 1H NMR spectrum (see ) after addition of a resolving agentthe alkaloid (−)-cinchonidinerevealing multiple resonances for protons, diastereotopic by external comparison, present in the diastereoisomeric acid–base pair (salts).
elements.clean_text: Further proof that the R p and S p enantiomers of 5 are resolvable comes from its 1H NMR spectrum (see ) after addition of a resolving agentthe alkaloid (-)-cinchonidinerevealing multiple resonances for protons, diastereotopic by external comparison, present in the diastereoisomeric acid-base pair (salts).

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectrum of the dimethyl ester (S1 in ) of 5 indicates that it is also, as expected, conformationally rigid and so exists as resolvable enantiomers which, in this instance, have been separated (resolved) by chiral HPLC.
elements.clean_text: The 1H NMR spectrum of the dimethyl ester (S1 in ) of 5 indicates that it is also, as expected, conformationally rigid and so exists as resolvable enantiomers which, in this instance, have been separated (resolved) by chiral HPLC.

elements.content: The four methyl groups present in S3 enhance its solubility in organic solvents.
elements.clean_text: The four methyl groups present in S3 enhance its solubility in organic solvents.

cln_elements.content: The pillar[5]arene-based strut 5 has been used to synthesize a MOF (Figure a) with Zn4O secondary building units (SBUs) which is isoreticular to MOF-5. P5A-MOF-1 was prepared in a conventional manner by heating a mixture of 5 and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in DMF at 100 °C over 24 h. The crystals (Figure a) of P5A-MOF-1 are cubic and transparent. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed their crystallinity (Figure b), while thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to determine their thermal stability: a one-step TGA profile shows that P5A-MOF-1 is stable to 450 °C. Crystals of P5A-MOF-1 were activated using supercritical CO2, and a NLDFT surface area of 300 m2 g–1 was obtained from a CO2 isotherm (see ).
cln_elements.clean_text: The pillar[5]arene-based strut 5 has been used to synthesize a MOF (Figure a) with Zn4O secondary building units (SBUs) which is isoreticular to MOF-5. P5A-MOF-1 was prepared in a conventional manner by heating a mixture of 5 and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in DMF at 100 °C over 24 h. The crystals (Figure a) of P5A-MOF-1 are cubic and transparent. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed their crystallinity (Figure b), while thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to determine their thermal stability: a one-step TGA profile shows that P5A-MOF-1 is stable to 450 °C. Crystals of P5A-MOF-1 were activated using supercritical CO2, and a NLDFT surface area of 300 m2g-1 was obtained from a CO2 isotherm (see ).

other properties: NLDFT surface area of 300 m^2 g^–1

CCDC 896924.

cln_elements.content:
Mole Ratio of Guest to Organic Strut in <bold>P5A-MOF-1</bold> and <bold>IRMOF-16-OPX</bold>, Obtained from <sup>1</sup>H NMR Spectra after Guest Uptake and Digestion of MOF<xref rid="t1fn1"></xref> P5A-MOF-1 IRMOF-16-OPX Single-Guest Uptake Experiments G1 + 0.755 0.121 G2 2+ 0.366 0.125 G3 0.293 0.084 Two-Guest Uptake Experiments G1 + + G2 2+ 0.091 G1 + /0.176 G2 2+ 0.089 G1 + /0.069 G2 2+ G1 + + G3 0.090 G1 + /0.127 G3 0.027 G1 + /0.032 G3 G2 2+ + G3 0.310 G2 2+ /0.100 G3 0.068 G2 2+ /0.014 G3

Uptake with a single guest was performed with a saturated solution of the guest in Me2CO. Uptake with two guests was performed in a Me2CO solution with each guest at 40.0 mM. K a values of guest with 5 determined by 1H NMR titration in CD3COCD3: G1 + , 43.2 ± 2.9 M–1; G2 2+ , 170 ± 50 M–1; G3, 66.2 ± 1.9 M–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Table 1. Mole Ratio of Guest to Organic Strut in P5A-MOF-1 and IRMOF-16-OPX, Obtained from 1H NMR Spectra after Guest Uptake and Digestion of MOF[^a]

| Single-Guest Uptake Experiments | P5A-MOF-1 | IRMOF-16-OPX |
|--------------------------------|----------|-------------|
| G1+                            | 0.755    | 0.121       |
| G22+                           | 0.366    | 0.125       |
| G3                             | 0.293    | 0.084       |
| Two-Guest Uptake Experiments   |          |             |
| G1+ + G22+                     | 0.091 G1+/0.176 G22+ | 0.089 G1+/0.069 G22+ |
| G1+ + G3                       | 0.090 G1+/0.127 G3 | 0.027 G1+/0.032 G3 |
| G22+ + G3                      | 0.310 G22+/0.100 G3 | 0.068 G22+/0.014 G3 |

[^a]: Uptake with a single guest was performed with a saturated solution of the guest in Me2CO. Uptake with two guests was performed in a Me2CO solution with each guest at 40.0 mM. Ka values of guest with 5 determined by 1H NMR titration in CD3COCD3: G1+, 43.2 ± 2.9 M–1; G22+, 170 ± 50 M–1; G3, 66.2 ± 1.9 M–1.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of A1/A2-Difunctionalized Pillar[5]­arene Organic Strut<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

In the X-ray crystal structure of 3, C is gray, O is red, H is white; alkyl H atoms are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of A1/A2-Difunctionalized Pillar[5]arene Organic Strut      a In the X-ray crystal structure of 3, C is gray, O is red, H is white; alkyl H atoms are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Solid-state structure of 5 (C is gray, O is red) which displays planar chirality and does not racemize between the R p-5 (left) and S p-5 (right) enantiomers. A DMF molecule and hydrogens have been removed from the structure to aid visual clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Solid-state structure of 5 (C is gray, O is red) which displays planar chirality and does not racemize between the R p-5 (left) and S p-5 (right) enantiomers. A DMF molecule and hydrogens have been removed from the structure to aid visual clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) Model of P5A-MOF-1 (pillar[5]arene macrocycles are red, terphenylene moieties are black, zinc SBUs are yellow). (b) Experimental PXRD pattern for P5A-MOF-1 (black), calculated PXRD patterns for P5A-MOF-1 in a P1 space group (red) and a Pm3m space group (green), and PXRD pattern for IRMOF-16 (blue). See SI for full PXRD of P5A-MOF-1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Model of P5A-MOF-1 (pillar[5]arene macrocycles are red, terphenylene moieties are black, zinc SBUs are yellow). (b) Experimental PXRD pattern for P5A-MOF-1 (black), calculated PXRD patterns for P5A-MOF-1 in a P1 space group (red) and a Pm3m space group (green), and PXRD pattern for IRMOF-16 (blue). See SI for full PXRD of P5A-MOF-1.

cln_elements.content: (Top) Optical microscopy images of P5A-MOF-1 (a) with no guest (scale bar, 200 μm), (b) after uptake of G2·2PF6 (scale bar, 100 μm, and (c) after uptake of G3 (scale bar, 100 μm). (Bottom) Electron-poor compounds used in guest uptake studies with P5A-MOF-1: N-hexylpyridinium cation (G1 +), N,N′-dihexyl-4,4-bipyridinium dication (G2 2+), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (G3).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (Top) Optical microscopy images of P5A-MOF-1 (a) with no guest (scale bar, 200 μm), (b) after uptake of G2⋅2PF6 (scale bar, 100 μm, and (c) after uptake of G3 (scale bar, 100 μm). (Bottom) Electron-poor compounds used in guest uptake studies with P5A-MOF-1: N-hexylpyridinium cation (G1 +), N,N'-dihexyl-4,4-bipyridinium dication (G2 2+), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (G3).
